0.name: Background
structure: Represents non-labeled or non-specific tissue in tractography imaging
Includes regions not assigned to a specific white matter tract or anatomical structure
Typically used as a reference or null label in segmentation and visualization
function: No specific neurological function
Serves as a placeholder in imaging datasets to differentiate labeled tracts from surrounding tissue
Ensures accurate visualization of tractography by providing contrast to labeled structures

1.name: Left-LGN
structure: Left Lateral Geniculate Nucleus
Located in the posterior thalamus, beneath the pulvinar
Six-layered structure with distinctive lamination pattern
Receives direct input from retinal ganglion cells via the optic tract
function: Primary relay center for visual information from the retina to the primary visual cortex (V1)
Processes contralateral visual field information (right visual field)
Segregates and maintains retinotopic organization of visual inputs
Critical for conscious visual perception and spatial processing

2.name: Right-LGN
structure: Right Lateral Geniculate Nucleus
Located in the posterior thalamus, beneath the pulvinar
Six-layered structure with distinctive lamination pattern
Receives direct input from retinal ganglion cells via the optic tract
function: Primary relay center for visual information from the retina to the primary visual cortex (V1)
Processes contralateral visual field information (left visual field)
Segregates and maintains retinotopic organization of visual inputs
Critical for conscious visual perception and spatial processing

3.name: Left-MGN
structure: Left Medial Geniculate Nucleus
Located in the posterior thalamus, medial to the LGN
Divided into ventral (principal), dorsal, and medial divisions
Receives auditory inputs via the inferior colliculus and lateral lemniscus
function: Primary auditory relay nucleus transmitting to the primary auditory cortex
Processes tonotopically organized auditory information
Ventral division processes basic auditory features; dorsal/medial divisions integrate multimodal inputs
Essential for sound localization, pitch discrimination, and auditory attention

4.name: Right-MGN
structure: Right Medial Geniculate Nucleus
Located in the posterior thalamus, medial to the LGN
Divided into ventral (principal), dorsal, and medial divisions
Receives auditory inputs via the inferior colliculus and lateral lemniscus
function: Primary auditory relay nucleus transmitting to the primary auditory cortex
Processes tonotopically organized auditory information
Ventral division processes basic auditory features; dorsal/medial divisions integrate multimodal inputs
Essential for sound localization, pitch discrimination, and auditory attention

5.name: Left-PuI
structure: Left Pulvinar Inferior
Inferior portion of the pulvinar complex in the posterior thalamus
Large nuclear mass with connections to visual association areas
Bordered by the lateral and medial geniculate bodies
function: Integrates visual information with other sensory modalities
Participates in visual attention and visuospatial processing
Connects with temporal and parietal association cortices
Involved in higher-order processing of visual stimuli and visual salience

6.name: Left-PuM
structure: Left Pulvinar Medial
Medial portion of the pulvinar nuclear complex
Has extensive connections with association cortices in parietal and temporal lobes
Receives input from superior colliculus and visual cortical areas
function: Facilitates multimodal sensory integration
Participates in attentional processing and directing visual attention
Coordinates communication between different cortical areas
Important for visual cognition and attentional selection

7.name: Left-L-Sg
structure: Left Limitans-Suprageniculate Nucleus
Located at the posterior aspect of the thalamus
Positioned superior to the medial geniculate nucleus
Small nuclear group with connections to limbic and paralimbic regions
function: Processes multimodal sensory information, particularly auditory and somatosensory
Projects to limbic structures including amygdala and insular cortex
Involved in emotional responses to sensory stimuli
Contributes to contextual sensory processing and affective responses

8.name: Left-VPL
structure: Left Ventral Posterolateral Nucleus
Located in the lateral thalamus, posterior to VL nucleus
Contains somatotopically organized neurons
Receives input from the medial lemniscus and spinothalamic tracts
function: Primary relay nucleus for somatosensory information from the body (excluding face)
Processes touch, vibration, proprioception, and pain sensation
Projects to primary somatosensory cortex (S1)
Essential for conscious perception of tactile and proprioceptive stimuli

9.name: Left-CM
structure: Left Centromedian Nucleus
Large nucleus within the intralaminar complex
Located in the central portion of the thalamus
Rich in connections with striatum and motor cortices
function: Major component of the ascending reticular activating system
Important for arousal, attention, and consciousness
Provides excitatory input to the striatum for motor control
Involved in pain processing and modulation of sensorimotor integration

10.name: Left-VLa
structure: Left Ventral Lateral Anterior Nucleus
Anterior portion of the ventral lateral nuclear complex
Receives input from the globus pallidus interna via the thalamic fasciculus
Dense connections with premotor cortex and supplementary motor area
function: Important relay in the pallidothalamic pathway of motor control
Involved in the planning and initiation of voluntary movements
Modulates cortical motor activity based on basal ganglia input
Dysfunction contributes to movement disorders like Parkinson's disease

11.name: Left-PuA
structure: Left Pulvinar Anterior
Anterior portion of the pulvinar complex
Connected with parietal association cortices
Forms part of the posterior thalamic region
function: Involved in higher-order visual processing and visual attention
Participates in visuospatial integration and coordinate transformations
Contributes to cross-modal integration of visual information
Important for directed attention and visual cognition

12.name: Left-MDm
structure: Left Mediodorsal Nucleus, Medial Part
Medial portion of the mediodorsal nucleus
Rich in connections with limbic structures and orbital frontal cortex
Receives input from amygdala, olfactory structures, and hypothalamus
function: Involved in emotional processing and affective behavior
Participates in olfactory processing and discrimination
Contributes to executive functions through prefrontal connections
Important for emotional aspects of decision-making and motivation

13.name: Left-Pf
structure: Left Parafascicular Nucleus
Component of the intralaminar nuclear group
Located medial to the CM nucleus
Extensive connections with striatum and frontal cortices
function: Involved in arousal and attention mechanisms
Contributes to sensorimotor integration and pain processing
Projects to striatum to modulate motor control
Participates in learning and behavioral flexibility

14.name: Left-VAmc
structure: Left Ventral Anterior Nucleus, Magnocellular Part
Anterior thalamic nucleus composed of large neurons
Receives major input from the substantia nigra pars reticulata
Projects primarily to supplementary motor area and premotor cortex
function: Relay for nigral inputs to cortical motor areas
Involved in the planning and initiation of movement
Contributes to motor learning and coordination
Important for eye movement control and oculomotor function

15.name: Left-MDl
structure: Left Mediodorsal Nucleus, Lateral Part
Lateral portion of the mediodorsal nucleus
Densely connected with dorsolateral prefrontal cortex
Receives inputs from basal ganglia and limbic structures
function: Critical for higher cognitive functions and executive control
Supports working memory and cognitive flexibility
Involved in decision-making and strategic planning
Dysfunction linked to cognitive symptoms in schizophrenia

16.name: Left-CeM
structure: Left Central Medial Nucleus
Midline component of the intralaminar nuclei
Located in the central portion of the thalamus
Widespread projections to striatum and cerebral cortex
function: Component of the ascending reticular activating system
Important for arousal, consciousness, and attention
Modulates cortical excitability and sensory processing
Involved in pain perception and nociceptive processing

17.name: Left-VA
structure: Left Ventral Anterior Nucleus
Located in the anterior thalamus
Receives input primarily from basal ganglia
Projects to premotor and prefrontal cortices
function: Important relay in the basal ganglia-thalamocortical circuit
Involved in motor planning and initiation
Contributes to cognitive aspects of motor control
Dysfunction associated with movement disorders

18.name: Left-MV(Re)
structure: Left Midline Ventral Nucleus (Reuniens)
Midline thalamic nucleus located near the third ventricle
Substantial connections with hippocampus and prefrontal cortex
Receives inputs from limbic and brainstem structures
function: Coordinates communication between hippocampus and prefrontal cortex
Critical for memory formation and spatial navigation
Involved in fear memory and emotional processing
Important for cognitive flexibility and switching between tasks

19.name: Left-R
structure: Left Reticular Nucleus
Shell-like structure surrounding the lateral aspect of the thalamus
Composed entirely of GABAergic inhibitory neurons
Receives collaterals from thalamocortical and corticothalamic fibers
function: Provides inhibitory control over thalamic relay nuclei
Regulates thalamocortical transmission and rhythmicity
Critical for selective attention and filtering of sensory information
Important in the generation of sleep spindles and thalamic oscillations

20.name: Left-VM
structure: Left Ventromedial Nucleus
Located in the ventral thalamus, medial to the VL nucleus
Receives input from the cerebellum and substantia nigra
Projects to primary motor cortex and supplementary motor area
function: Relay for cerebellar motor information to cortical motor areas
Involved in coordination and fine control of movement
Participates in posture maintenance and locomotion
Important for the smooth execution of voluntary movements

21.name: Left-CL
structure: Left Centrolateral Nucleus
Component of the intralaminar nuclear group
Located lateral to the central median nucleus
Widespread projections to striatum and cerebral cortex
function: Part of the ascending reticular activating system
Involved in arousal, wakefulness, and attention
Contributes to sensorimotor integration
Modulates pain perception and nociceptive processing

22.name: Left-PuL
structure: Left Pulvinar Lateral
Lateral portion of the pulvinar complex
Connected with visual association areas and superior temporal gyrus
Largest subdivision of the pulvinar
function: Involved in higher-order visual processing and attention
Contributes to visual motion processing and spatial awareness
Participates in visual object recognition
Important for visually guided behavior and attention

23.name: Left-Pt
structure: Left Paratenial Nucleus
Small anterior nucleus adjacent to the midline
Connected with limbic structures, particularly the amygdala
Located near the anterior pole of the thalamus
function: Participates in limbic circuit processing
Involved in emotional and affective processing
Contributes to stress responses and anxiety
Facilitates communication between amygdala and prefrontal regions

24.name: Left-AV
structure: Left Anteroventral Nucleus
Component of the anterior nuclear group
Receives input from the mammillary bodies via the mammillothalamic tract
Projects to cingulate cortex and parahippocampal regions
function: Key component of the Papez circuit for memory processing
Critical for spatial navigation and orientation
Involved in episodic memory formation and retrieval
Contributes to emotional processing via limbic connections

25.name: Left-Pc
structure: Left Paracentral Nucleus
Member of the intralaminar nuclear group
Located in the central region of the thalamus
Connected with sensorimotor cortices and striatum
function: Contributes to arousal and attention mechanisms
Involved in sensorimotor integration
Participates in pain processing and modulation
Part of the ascending reticular activating system

26.name: Left-VLp
structure: Left Ventral Lateral Posterior Nucleus
Posterior division of the ventral lateral nuclear complex
Receives major cerebellar input via the superior cerebellar peduncle
Projects primarily to primary motor cortex
function: Primary relay for cerebellar input to motor cortex
Critical for coordination of voluntary movement
Facilitates smooth execution of planned movements
Essential for motor learning and adaptation

27.name: Left-LP
structure: Left Lateral Posterior Nucleus
Located in the posterior thalamus, anterior to the pulvinar
Connected with posterior parietal cortex and visual association areas
Receives input from superior colliculus and pretectum
function: Involved in visuospatial processing and attention
Contributes to sensorimotor integration
Participates in coordinate transformations for visual guidance of movement
Important for spatial awareness and directing attention in space

28.name: Left-LD
structure: Left Lateral Dorsal Nucleus
Located in the dorsal thalamus, posterolateral to anterior nuclei
Connected with posterior cingulate and retrosplenial cortex
Receives input from hippocampal formation
function: Involved in spatial navigation and orientation
Contributes to memory processing and spatial cognition
Participates in limbic functions via cingulate connections
Important for contextual processing of spatial information

29.name: Right-PuI
structure: Right Pulvinar Inferior
Inferior portion of the pulvinar complex in the posterior thalamus
Large nuclear mass with connections to visual association areas
Bordered by the lateral and medial geniculate bodies
function: Integrates visual information with other sensory modalities
Participates in visual attention and visuospatial processing
Connects with temporal and parietal association cortices
Involved in higher-order processing of visual stimuli and visual salience

structure: Right Paratenial Nucleus
Small anterior nucleus adjacent to the midline

Located near the anterior pole of the thalamus
function: Participates in limbic circuit processing

function: Key component of the Papez circuit for memory processing
Critical for spatial navigation and orientation
Involved in episodic memory formation and retrieval
Contributes to emotional processing via limbic connections

51.name: Right-LP
structure: Lateral posterior nucleus of the right thalamus
Located in the dorsolateral thalamus, posterior to the ventral nuclei
Receives inputs from the superior colliculus and pretectum
Projects primarily to the posterior parietal cortex and parts of the visual association cortex
function: Involved in higher-order visual processing and visuospatial integration
Facilitates integration of visual information with other sensory modalities
Contributes to spatial awareness and attention mechanisms
Participates in visual guidance of movement and spatial navigation

52.name: Right-LD
structure: Lateral dorsal nucleus of the right thalamus
Located in the dorsolateral thalamic region, adjacent to the lateral posterior nucleus
Receives afferents from the hippocampal formation and mammillary bodies
Projects to posterior cingulate cortex and parahippocampal regions
function: Participates in spatial memory processing and navigation
Functions within the extended hippocampal-diencephalic memory system
Contributes to emotional and cognitive aspects of memory formation
Involved in the integration of spatial information with episodic memory
